Charges: *18:371 Conspiracy to willfully make a bomb threat; *18:844(e) Willfully making a bomb threat; *26.5861(d) Possession of a non-registered destructive device
Short narrative: In October 1997, in Tulsa, Oklahoma, white supremacist James Viefhaus, Jr., 28, was charged with conspiracy to willfully make bomb threat, willfully making a bomb threat, and possession of a non-registered destructive device. This was carried out through Viefhaus leaving a phone message threatening to bomb 15 U.S. cities via an Aryan Intelligence Network hotline operated by Viefhaus and his fiancé at the time, Carol E. Howe, both the founding and only members of the National Socialist Alliance of Oklahoma. Viefhaus was motivated by his right-wing beliefs as evidenced by his organization which sought for "the destruction of blacks, Jews, homosexuals, and federal law enforcement agents". Howe acted as an informant for the case and charged against her were dropped.
Source description: court documents, local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Stone, et al.
Charges: 18:2384.f Seditious Conspiracy; 18:2332aa.f Use of Certain Weapons of Mass Destruction; 18:842p.f Teaching or Demonstrating Making of Explosive Devices; 18:924c.f Violent Crime/drugs/machine Gun [4 Counts]; *26:5841f Registration of Firearms
Short narrative: Defendants charged in the 'STONE' group were members of the group Hutaree. According to the indictment, Hutaree members view local, state, and federal law enforcement as the “brotherhood”, their enemy, and have been preparing to engage them in armed conflict. The indictment also alleges that the Hutaree planned to kill an unidentified member of local law enforcement and then attack the law enforcement officers who would gather in Michigan for the funeral. According to the plan, the Hutaree would attack law enforcement vehicles during the funeral procession with improvised explosive devices with explosively formed projectiles, which, according to the indictment, constitute weapons of mass destruction. Subsequently, and in furtherance of this plan, David Brian Stone, the Hutaree’s leader, obtained information about such devices over the Internet and e-mailed diagrams of such devices to a person he believed capable of manufacturing the devices. Additionally all nine defndants were charged with carrying or possessing a firearm during a crime of violence on at least one occasion. All of the defendants pleaded not guilty and were aquitted with the exception of David Brian Stone Sr., Joshua John Clough, and Joshua Matthew Stone who pleaded not guilty and were found guilty on some charges and sentenced to time served of 28 months.
Source description: Court documents, Governmental Reports and Release, Charging Documents

Additional details: 3 years supervised release
Short narrative: In 2013, agents with the FBI arrested militia member Buford Braden “Bucky” Rogers, of Montevideo, Minnesota, after discovering two Molotov cocktails, two “black powder and nail devices,” a pipe bomb, and a semi‐automatic rifle at his home. Rogers was a convicted felon prohibited from possessing firearms. An FBI affidavit asserted that Rogers regularly talked of plans to use his militia group, a tiny group called the Black Snake Militia, to cut off communications to the City of Montevideo, raid the National Guard Armory, and bomb the Montevideo Police Department. Rogers pleaded guilty to being a felon in possession of a firearm and possessing an unregistered destructive device and received a 40‐ month prison sentence.

Reason for inclusion: Obvious socio-political aim AND State speech act
Name of case: United States of America v. Peace et al.
Charges: 18:371f Conspiracy to Defraud the United States; 18:2332aa.f Use of Certain Weapons of Mass Destruction
Additional details: 5 years of supervised release, 100 hours of community service
Short narrative: Terry Eugene Peace, Brian Edward Cannon and Cory Robert Williamson, attempted to obtain thermite and pipe bombs in order to launch terrorist attacks against the federal government. Based on online comments they made, the trio seem to have hoped to spark a government overreaction that would cause the militia movement to rise up. Cannon, Peace and Williamson targeted the infrastructure supporting their federal agency targets because they believed this would reduce the amount of unnecessary casualties and make it difficult for the government to respond to their attack. When going to pick up the pipe bombs the men were intercepted by police due to work with an informant. All defendants pleaded guilty and were sentenced to 144 months in prison.

Short narrative: On September 25, 2016, Stephen Plato McRae fired shots at the Buckskin Electrical Substation, causing the substation to overheat and fail. According to the state, he told a confidential informant he was trying to "destroy industrial capitalism" and "do millions of dollars of damage to the fossil fuel industry.”

Charges: Possesion of unregistered explosive device, unlawful storage of explosive material
Additional details: three years supervised release
Short narrative: (Army National Guard) Brandon Russell is a dangerous Neo-Nazi leader who was found to have lethal bomb-making materials in his Florida apartment after his roommate shot two of their other roommates. Russell is a dual citizen with the US and the Bahamas and an active duty member of the Florida National Guard. Russell and his roommate Devon Arthurs (the shooter) were co-founders of the Atomwaffen Division. Russell was not found to be connected to the murder of his roommates. The bomb-making materials were found amongst other neo-Nazi propaganda, including a framed picture of Timothy McVeigh and the Turner Diaries. Russell's attorney argues that Russell has mental deficiencies (ADHD and Autism) and that the bomb-makng materials were not going to be used. One of Russell's murdered roommates, Andrew Oneschuk, was also a member of AWD and had ties to the Azov Battalion in Ukraine.

Additional details: Initially was ruled incompetent to stand trial due to self-inflicted brain damange. After spending months in a mental hospital, he was deemed competent to stand trial.
Short narrative: On December 22, 2017, in Reston, VA, Nicholas Giampa, 17, was charged with two counts of murder. This was carried out by Giampa sneaking into his girlfriends home, when her parents discovered him, he drew a handgun and shot both parents before unsuccessfully attempting suicide by shooting himself. As @doctorpepper35, Giampa tweeted about his hatred of transgender people and his admiration for Adolf Hitler. He tweeted about using Jews as target practice. Online, Giampa had repeatedly interacted with white supremacist groups, in particular the Atomwaffen Division. The Frickers had staged an intervention for their daughter to keep her from dating an "outspoken neo-Nazi" and had even reported Giampa's hate speech to the special education high school the two attended. Initially, Giampa was ruled incompetent to stand trial due to brain damage from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head. After spending months in a mental hospital, Giampa was deemed competent to stand trial. Giampa's sentencing is coded as data not available because his records are not available through Fairfax County Circuit Court, and his name has not appeared in the news since 2019.
Source description: News Articles, Local News Nrticles

Name of case: THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF MICHIGAN v. JOSEPH MATTHEW MORRISON et. al.
Charges: MCL 750.543k(1)(b) Terrorist Acts - providing material support; *MCL 750.227b Weapons - felony firearm
Additional details: Defendant agreed to testify truthfully against his co-defendants at their upcoming August trial if asked to in exchange, the state dismissed a felony firearm charge.
Short narrative: On October 7, 2020, 8 individuals associated with the Wolverine Watchmen (Paul Bellar, Shawn Fix, Edward Molitar, Michael Null, William Null, Peter Musico, Joseph Morrison, and Brian Higgins), were indicted in a Michigan state court for providing material support to the group who plotted to kidnap the governor Whitmer of Michigan. Defendants Morrison and Muscio are co-founders of the Wolverine Watchmen, a right-wing militia group associated with the boogaloo movement. These eight defendants were not accused of directly participating in the kidnapping plot but rather providing material support for Adam Fox's plan to kidnap the governor. Adam Fox aimed to kidnap the democratic government and trigger a civil war before the 2020 election leading to societal collapse. Bellar, Morrison, and Musico pleaded not guilty and were each sentenced to a maximum of 20 years in prison. Molitor and both Null brothers pleaded not guilty and were acquitted.
Source description: Charging Documents, Governmental reports and releases, News articles, Local news articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Cameron Emerson Casey Rankin
Charges: 18:922(g)(4) Any person who has been "adjudicated as a mental defective" or "committed to a mental institution" is prohibited under Federal law from shipping, transporting, receiving, or possessing any firearm or ammunition
Additional details: "FBI’s JTTF is conducting this investigation with assistance from the ATF...This case falls with the purview of the Attorney General’s Task Force to Combat Violent Anti-Government Extremism. Launched in June 2020, the Task Force is dedicated to supporting the investigation and prosecution of any person or group who commits violence in the name of an anti-government ideology....This case is also a part of Project Guardian, which is the Department of Justice’s signature initiative to reduce gun violence and enforce federal firearms laws. (DOJ Press release)"
Short narrative: "A federal criminal complaint filed...[which] charges 21–year-old Cameron Emerson Casey Rankin with one count of being a prohibited person in possession of a firearm as a result of previously being committed to a mental institution. FBI agents arrested Rankin...and recovered a black semi-automatic rifle during the execution of a search warrant at his residence...According to the criminal complaint, Rankin was in unlawful possession of a firearm, with the capability and means to affect violence in furtherance of his beliefs and has expressed a desire to overthrow the government, specifically, the “three letter agencies” such as ATF, FBI and IRS...Rankin attempted to purchase two long guns from a San Antonio retail outlet on March 23, 2018, but was denied the firearms transactions under the “Prohibited Category” for previously being committed to a mental institution. After being warned by agents with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) that he was a prohibited person, Rankin posted pictures of himself with a firearm on social media. On May 30, 2020, Rankin and others, carrying long guns and pistols, appeared at the Alamo in downtown San Antonio to attend a protest in reaction to the death of George Floyd. The next day, Rankin posted on his Facebook account photos of himself and others carrying a firearm at the protest as well as comments about his disdain for police including, “…hope they burn the precinct down” and “I’m BOOGALOO we hate police.”...on August 4, 2020, Rankin posted a “selfie” photo on his Facebook timeline showing him holding a black, semi-automatic rifle in a vertical position against his shoulder with his finger on the trigger. Rankin posted other photos which included a quote, stating, “Diligently Plotting to Take Over the World in order to Leave You Alone”. On August 11, 2020, Rankin arrived at the airport in Manchester, New Hampshire. He flew out of San Antonio International Airport the previous day. Rankin checked a semiautomatic handgun in his luggage while at the ticket counter, but missed a connecting flight in Philadelphia, PA. Upon his arrival in Manchester, Rankin was met inside the terminal by ATF agents who served Rankin written notice that he is prohibited from possessing firearms. The agents also provided him with copies of his mental health records. Agents seized the handgun and ammunition from inside Rankin’s luggage. Rankin threw the notice letter and mental health records in the trash receptacle before leaving the airport terminal. (DOJ press release)"
Source description: DOJ OPA release, Court Documents, News

Short narrative: On December 16, 2020, Adam Fox, Barry Croft Jr., Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were indicted following a plot to kidnap the governor of Michigan. The men trained together and then planned to kidnap Governor Whitmer before the November 2020 Election. According to the SS Indictment, defendants Adam Fox and Barry Croft Jr. were affiliated with the “Three Percenter” movement (sometimes rendered III%), while defendants Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were members of the Wolverine Watchmen, a Michigan-based “militia” group with similar anti-government views. Ty Garbin entered a guilty plea in January 2020 to the original indictment charging him with conspiracy to kidnap Governor Whitmer and was sentenced to 75 months in prison. In April 2021, a Superseeding Indictment was issued to the five remaining defendants. Harris and Caserta pleaded not guilty and were both acquitted of all charges. Franks pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 48 months in prison. Fox and Croft Jr. pleaded not guilty and were convicted by jury trial in August 2022 of conspiracy to kidnap the governor and conspiracy to use weapons of mass destruction against persons or property. Croft was additionally convicted of knowingly possessing an unregistered destructive device, specifically an improvised explosive wrapped in pennies for shrapnel. Fox was sentenced to 192 months in prison, and Croft was sentenced to 235 months in prison.

Numerous photos depict the group participating in the march with the Proud Boys on Constitution Ave. as well as interacting with other known Proud Boys members just before the Capitol was breached. Kuehne is a retired Marine Corps officer after 22 years of service. Chrestman is a veteran of the US army. The Konold siblings are from Arizona.

Name of case: United States of America v. Christian Alexander Secor
Charges: 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; *18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder; *18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers; *18:1752(a)(1) Entering and remaining in a restricted Building or Grounds; *18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a restricted Building or Grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(A) Entering and Remaining on the Floor of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(B) Entering and Remaining in the Gallery of Congress; *40:5104(e)(2)(C) Entering and Remaining in Certain Rooms in the Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Resident of CA; "Sentenced 10/19/22 to 42 months in prison, three years of supervised release, $2,000 restitution."
Short narrative:
Christian Alexander Secor, 22 of California, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and was sentenced to 42 months of incarceration. On January 6, Secor entered the Capitol through the Senate doors, entered House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's office, and sat in Vice President Mike Pence's chair on the Senate Floor. He was also charged with assaulting police officers within the Capitol, but this charge and others were later dropped. He made  prior comments about civil war and wrote on his Twitter account that "We're legit in the Turner Diaries timeline." He was a UCLA student at the time of the riot and wore a red Make America Great Again hat and carried an America First flag. 

"The FBI said Secor is a self-identified Groyper, a network of "alt right figures who are vocal supporters of white supremacist and 'America First' podcaster Nick Fuentes. The FBI stated a tipster reported Secor founded the campus organization "America First Bruins" and is a member of Bruins Republicans. The FBI stated Secor can be seen in a group of rioters pushing their way into the building. Court documents state a tipster told the FBI that Secor moved back in with his mother after the riot, got rid of his phone and car and bragged that he would not be caught for his involvement." (USA Today)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, News articles

Name of case: United States of America v. Danny Jo Thompson ll
Charges: 18:922a(6) False Statement During Purchase of Firearm; 18:922(o) Illegal Possession of a Machine Gun; 18:2&922(o) Illegal Possession of a Machine Gun, aiding and abetting
Short narrative: On October 2, 2019, FBI attempted to arrest Eric Allport in Madison Heights, Michigan. Allport was shot and killed after opening fire and wounding one FBI agent. Danny Jo Thompson ll was arrested later that day for supplying Allport with a machine gun that was in Allports vehicle at the time of his arrest. Allport was killed before he reached his vehicle. Thompson and Allport were members of the Bogoloo movement and shared strong anti-police attitudes. Text messages proved that Thompson was aware that Allport was a convicted felon and knew that Allport was planning to use the acquired machine gun to kill law enforcement.

Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) - Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) - Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) - Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) - Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building
Additional details: Arrested 1/21/21; Pled guily to single misdemeanor; "Sentenced 10/1 to two years of probation, the first three months of which are to be served in home confinement; $500 restitution to the Architect of the Capitol; 80 hours of community service."
Short narrative: Andrew Ryan Bennett, a Columbia, Maryland Proud Boy, "livestreamed from inside the Capitol on Jan. 6. In the four videos Bennett broadcast to Facebook, he wears a baseball hat adorned with the “Proud Boys” motto. In one of the videos, Bennett says, “ if you can hear me, share my stream in Discord for me,” seemingly referring to the messaging platform that’s been used by the alt-right. At one point, he chanted “break it down!” with a crowd—referring to a door located in the Speaker’s Lobby that was barricaded by police. Air Force veteran Ashli Babbitt, one of the four pro-Trump protesters who died on Jan. 6, was fatally shot by a police officer while attempting to break into the Speaker’s Lobby...Bennett shared conspiracy theories online prior to the insurrection. On Jan. 4, Bennett posted a conspiracy-laden message, including his belief that President Joe Biden stole the election and Hunter Biden’s laptop....On Jan. 11, Bennett admitted to federal agents that he went to D.C. and “that he knew it was wrong” to storm the Capitol. (Daily Beast)"

Charges: 18:731 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Civil Disorder; 18:1361, 2 Government property or contracts; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(4), 2 Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds
Additional details: Also facing three unrelated, state-level gun charges; Resident of Syracuse, NY
Short narrative: Matthew J. Greene, 33, of Syracuse, NY, and William Joseph Pepe, 31, of Beacon, NY were charged with Conspiracy, Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding Abetting, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting, Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting, Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Disorderly Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds and Aiding and Abetting for their participation in the January 6th Capitol raid. Both Green and Pepe are memebers of Proud Boys and communicated with other Proud Boys memebrs prior to and during the Capitol raid. Additionally, Pepe posted a video of his presence inside the Capitol building, and Greene communicated via encrypted messaging channels confirming his participation. Greene initally pleaded not guilty, but later pleaded guilty per a plea bargain. The case is currently pending. [Note: Greene and Pepe were initially charged with Dominic Pezzola (A.K.A. Spazz, Spaz, Spazzo, Spazzolini; Case ID: 06062022_DP_4PROUDBOYS6), but Pezzola was removed from the case. Pezzola was named 3/7/22 in superseding indictment in new case, replacing 1:21-cr-52, and named again in a supersceding indictment 6/6/2022, having been added to the 4PROUDBOYS group case.)

Name of case: United States of America v. Fox, et al.
Charges: 18:1201(c) kidnapping, kidnapping conspiracy; 18:2332a(a)(2)(a), (a)(2)(c), 18:921(a)(4) use of certain weapons of mass destruction, conspiracy to use a weapon of mass destruction; *18:1201(c) kidnapping, kidnapping conspiracy
Additional details: 192 months custody, 5 years supervised release, fine of $1,250.00, and $100.00 special assessment
Short narrative: On December 16, 2020, Adam Fox, Barry Croft Jr., Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were indicted following a plot to kidnap the governor of Michigan. The men trained together and then planned to kidnap Governor Whitmer before the November 2020 Election. According to the SS Indictment, defendants Adam Fox and Barry Croft Jr. were affiliated with the “Three Percenter” movement (sometimes rendered III%), while defendants Ty Garbin, Kaleb Franks, Daniel Harris, and Brandon Caserta were members of the Wolverine Watchmen, a Michigan-based “militia” group with similar anti-government views. Ty Garbin entered a guilty plea in January 2020 to the original indictment charging him with conspiracy to kidnap Governor Whitmer and was sentenced to 75 months in prison. In April 2021, a Superseeding Indictment was issued to the five remaining defendants. Harris and Caserta pleaded not guilty and were both acquitted of all charges. Franks pleaded guilty and was sentenced to 48 months in prison. Fox and Croft Jr. pleaded not guilty and were convicted by jury trial in August 2022 of conspiracy to kidnap the governor and conspiracy to use weapons of mass destruction against persons or property. Croft was additionally convicted of knowingly possessing an unregistered destructive device, specifically an improvised explosive wrapped in pennies for shrapnel. Fox was sentenced to 192 months in prison, and Croft was sentenced to 235 months in prison.

Name of case: United States of America v. Rush, et al.
Charges: 18:1512(k) Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Offical Proceedings; *18:1512(c)(1) Destruction of Records in Official Proceedings; *18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of Official Proceedings
Additional details: 3 years of supervised release; a $100 special assessment, and a forfeiture of firearms, ammunition, and electronics seized from defendant. A voluntary surrender order will be filed separately.
Short narrative: Jessie Alexander Rush, the founder, "commanding officer," and "major" of the "1st Detachment, 1st California Grizzly Scouts" militia group, was alleged to have purposefully impeded the federal investigation and trial of Steven Carrillo, a Grizzly Scouts member who murdered a federal Protective Service Officer (PSO) in Oakland, California. Rush and his codefendants were charged with Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Official Proceedings for conspiring to destroy communication records relating to the murder. The Facebook group’s description stated, “they say the west won’t boog,” a reference to the “boogaloo” movement. The indictment alleged that a member of the Grizzly Scouts exchanged messages on the WhatsApp group with other Grizzly Scouts, in which that member allegedly told the group that he was preparing to engage in a shoot-out with law enforcement. Rush immediately instructed the Grizzly Scout member on the WhatsApp group to delete evidence on his phone. Rush, Blancas, Ybarra and Miksch then deleted records of their Whatsapp group, including the prior discussions regarding violence against law enforcement and Carrillo’s message to the group—“Dudes i offed a fed” indicating that he had killed a federal law enforcement officer. The indictment also alleges that less than an hour after the shooting in Ben Lomond, Blancas deleted files related to the Grizzly Scouts from a Dropbox account. Further, within hours of the shooting, members of the Grizzly Scouts, including Rush, Blancas, Ybarra, and Miksch allegedly began to reconnect on an alternative communications application. Moreover, the indictment alleges that the four defendants each deleted records of the WhatsApp group communications from their phones, including the prior discussions regarding violence against law enforcement. Rush pleaded guilty to Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Official Proceedings and was sentenced to 6 months in prison.
Source description: Charging documents, Court documents, Governmental reports and release

Short narrative: Robert Jesus Blancas, the "1st Lieutenant" of the "1st Detachment, 1st California Grizzly Scouts" militia group, was alleged to have purposefully impeded the federal investigation and trial of Steven Carrillo, a Grizzly Scouts member who murdered a federal Protective Service Officer (PSO) in Oakland, California. The Grizzly Scouts are a militia group associated with the "boogaloo" movement. Rush, Blancas, Ybarra and Miksch then deleted records of their Whatsapp group, including the prior discussions regarding violence against law enforcement and Carrillo’s message to the group—“Dudes i offed a fed” indicating that he had killed a federal law enforcement officer. The members then reconnected on alternative messaging servers where members repeatedly confirmed that they had destroyed evidence relating to the Grizzly Scouts, of which Carrillo was a member. Blancas was charged with Conspiracy to Destroy Records in Offical Proceedings, Destruction of Records in Official Proceedings, and Obstruction of Official Proceedings. Additional details: Resident of TX; Wore 3% t-shirt to Capitol riot though no additional confirmation is available; Joined Oath Keepers in 2012; Also arrested 1/5/21 by MPD for "crossing a police line during a protest" accorign to affidavit; "Sentenced 9/6/22 to 24 months of probation, including seven days of incarceration, 60 hours of community service, $500 restitution" (DOJ)
Short narrative: "Sean David Watson showed a coworker videos on his cellphone that he claimed to have taken inside the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, court documents indicate. That coworker then called the FBI to turn him in. In an initial interview with the FBI, Watson said he had participated in the Jan. 6 rally but denied being inside the Capitol building. In a second interview with agents, the FBI seized Watson's cellphone, and he admitted that he had entered the building. On that seized phone, law enforcement found photos from inside and outside the building and texts sent shortly after the riot, one of which read "I was one of the people that helped storm the capitol building and smash out the windows . We made history today. Proudest day of my life!” According to local news reports, Watson’s home is covered with messages, including “COVID1984," “Democrats stole the election" and "Veterans for Trump." NPR was not able to confirm his military history." (NPR)

Name of case: United States of America v. Mark Grods
Charges: 18:371 - Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 - Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting;
Additional details: Indicted by Bill of Information; Coordinated with Oath Keepers via Signal and provided firearms to be stored in a VA hotel; Resident of Mobile, AL
Short narrative: "Federal prosecutors allege that Mark Grods coordinated with members of the extremist anti-government militia known as the Oath Keepers to interfere with the certification of the Electoral College vote on Jan. 6. Ahead of the Capitol riot, court documents state, Grods joined a group chat named on the encrypted messaging app Signal called "DC OP: Jan 6 21." Grods "brought firearms to Washington, D.C., and eventually provided them to another individual to store in a Virginia hotel," while Grods stayed with other members of the group at the Mayflower Hotel in D.C., prosecutors say. While the Capitol riot was ongoing, Grods allegedly rode in a golf cart with others members of the Oath Keepers to the Capitol, then breached the building while carrying what prosecutors describe as a "large stick." Soon after, Grods exited the building as law enforcement used pepper balls to try to force people out of the Capitol, the court documents state. Later, he allegedly met with other members of the Oath Keepers outside the Capitol building, and, in the days after the riot, said he had deleted his messages on Signal. As part of a plea agreement, Grods has agreed to testify in court and sit for interviews with investigators." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents, Court documents, Governmental Reports and Release

Short narrative: Paul James Kryscuk, 35, Liam Collins, 21, Jordan Duncan, 26, Justin Wade Hermanson, 21, and Joseph Maurino, 22, conspired to manufacture, transport, and sell hard to obtain firearms and firearm parts in a manner that would hide these purchases from the federal government. Collins and Kryscuk were members of and made multiple posts on the “Iron March” forum, a gathering point for young neo-Nazis to organize and recruit for extremist organizations, until the forum was closed in late 2017. Collins and Duncan are former Marines assigned previously to Camp Lejeune in Jacksonville, NC. The defendants are also charged with conspiracy to damage the property of an energy facility in the US.

Additional details: Resident of AZ; Wore orange armband presumed to be signaling affiliation with Proud Boys, and was photographed marching with PBs, but denies affiliation with group. Micajah Jackson sentenced 3/24/22 to 36 months of probation, including 90 days in a residential re-entry center, $1,000 fine, $500 restitution.
Short narrative: "Jackson, whose social media pages say he's a 100% disabled Marine, surrendered to the FBI on May 18: The FBI stated in court documents that he posted photos on social media of himself on Jan. 6 in a plaid shirt and other clothing he wore to the riot, photos agents later used to identify him. He was dubbed #TartanPlaidPB by online sleuths who are researching those who participated in the Capitol riot, then turning that information over to the FBI. Jackson is seen in photos numerous times on Jan. 6 with Proud Boys from Arizona, and wore one of their orange arm bands, the FBI stated. However, in an interview with the FBI at his home, agents said Jackson told them he is not affiliated with the Proud Boys and doesn't support their ideology. He said they gave him the orange band and he stayed with them for protection because he had traveled to Washington, D.C. alone. However, the FBI noted that in December, one of his social media connections tagged him in a post about a group of Proud Boys being in New York City. In a social media post included in the court records, Jackson said he didn't agree with the "MAGA tribalism," and didn't commit any violence. Jackson stated in the post that he had evidence of BLM, Antifa, police officers and "Non Trump" extremists "causing the mayhem." Jackson also stated that he's a college student studying to be a political science professor. "My only love is the United States of America," he wrote. At the Capitol, records show he carried a U.S. flag and was with a crowd singing The Star-Spangled Banner after the detonation of an explosive device in the crowd. He then pointed toward the Senate Wing of the Capitol and moved that direction. The agents noted he was seen on video in Statuary Hall and other locations inside the Capitol." (USA Today)

Charges: 18:922(g)(2) Possession of Firearm by Fugitive from Justice
Additional details: Sentenced to time served, Supervised release of 18 months, fine of $100
Short narrative: "On March 24, 2022, Nathan A. Bergstrom, a 42-year-old resident of Arizona, was sentenced in the Western District of Kentucky to time served after pleading guilty to unlawful possession of a firearm. According to court records, Bergstrom is a “self proclaimed Boogaloo Boi” who was initially arrested at a Greyhound Bus Station in Phoenix, Arizona in January 2021. Bergstrom’s initial arrest was based on probable cause that he committed felony misconduct involving weapons, in violation of Arizona criminal code. After being released, Bergstrom failed to appear for his preliminary hearing, and a bench warrant was subsequently issued for his arrest. On March 13, 2021, Bergstrom was identified by the FBI as a participant in an event in Louisville, Kentucky, which was attended by multiple adherents of the Boogaloo movement. During the event, Bergstrom was arrested by law enforcement, who discovered a handgun on his person. A search warrant for Bergstrom’s cell phone also revealed screen shots of a pair of Greyhound bus tickets from New Mexico to Ohio, purchased under aliases, in an attempt to conceal Bergstrom’s identity and flee Arizona to avoid prosecution."

Name of case: United States of America v. David Nicholas Dempsey
Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Civil Disorder; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding; 18:111(a)(1) and 2 Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 18:111(a)(1) and (b) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers Using a Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(1) and (b)(1)(A) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(2) and (b)(1)(A) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 18:1752(a)(4) and (b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) and 2 Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building or Grounds; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building
Additional details: Resident of CA; Identified with aid from Sedition Hunters; Was arrested 10/1919 for spraying anti-Trump protestors with bear spray.
Short narrative: "David Dempsey came to the attention of federal investigators through public tips from the Sedition Hunters -- people researching the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol. On the day of the Capitol riot, federal prosecutors allege, Dempsey wore an American flag-themed neck gaiter as well as a combat-style helmet, camouflage pants and a tactical vest. In one video described in court documents, Dempsey stood in front of a gallows erected outside the Capitol and said that Democrats in Congress "need to hang from these motherf****** [pointing to gallows]," and that "Hopefully one day soon we really have someone hanging from one of these motherf******." During the riot, Dempsey allegedly used a lacrimal agent -- such as pepper spray -- as well as a crutch and a metal pole to attack police officers guarding the Capitol building. Dempsey was arrested in Santa Monica, Calif., in 2019 over allegedly using bear spray to attack anti-Trump protesters there. Dempsey pleaded no contest to a charge stemming from that incident. The Justice Department notes in its court filings that Dempsey can be seen in multiple photos from Jan. 6 wearing a black- and yellow-colored bracelet. Black and yellow are the colors associated with the far-right extremist group known as the Proud Boys. In one photo described in court documents, Dempsey made the OK sign while standing next to people wearing Proud Boys attire. The "OK" sign, which the Proud Boys frequently use, is often associated with supporters of white supremacy, according to the Anti-Defamation League. Dempsey was arrested on Aug. 26." (NPR)
Source description: Charging Documents

Name of case: United States of America v. Joshua Dillon Haynes
Charges: *18:1752(a)(1), (2), and (4) Unlawful entry on restricted grounds, disorderly conduct, act of physical violence on grounds; 18:1512(c)(2) and 2 Obstruction of an official proceeding; 18:1363 Destruction of property in special maritime and territorial jurisdiction; *40:5104(e)(2)(D) Violent entry or disorderly conduct; *40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical violence on grounds; *40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parade, dmonstrate, or picket in any of the Capitol Buildings
Additional details: Resident of VA, "Sentenced 2/2/23 to 32 months in prison, restitution, to be determined at a future date, and 36 months of supervised release"
Short narrative: Joshua Dillion Haynes, 39 of Virginia, pled guilty to Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Destruction of Property in the Territorial Jurisdiction. He was sentenced to 32 months in prison for his role in the Capitol Raid. He was recorded on video attacking members of the media at a staging area near the Capitol, crushing their equipment and stealing their camera. According to local news reporting, Haynes was angry specifically at CNN. "Court documents also show images taken from another video that allegedly show Haynes, along with two others, attempting to pull an air conditioning unit from outside the Capitol building. Haynes was identified by a tipster who used publicly available facial recognition software to match images from photos with a post from a Parler profile, and agents subsequently pulled the subscriber records to find a phone number and email address. Search warrant records for the phone reportedly show that Haynes used it the day of the riot to take pictures inside the Capitol and at the media staging area, and to text with friends. One selfie depicted Haynes inside the office of a U.S. senator, court documents indicate. Later, texts were allegedly exchanged between Haynes and other individuals that indicated he had broken windows and crawled into the Capitol. Prosecutors say one friend texted Haynes the message “dont [sic] be like antifa tearing stuff up.” Haynes replied, “ahhhh tooooo late,” “broke lotsa stuff,” and then “lol.” Haynes reportedly indicated he was seen destroying media equipment, saying "i Kicked the fake news a**" and "I am in the video destroying stuff but I'm wearing a mask." FBI agents went to Haynes' house and interviewed him at length. Haynes allegedly said he believed riot suspects were being treated badly in contrast to people who had participated in Black Lives Matter protests and that he respected those who used force against law enforcement to "stop the election from being stolen." Haynes attended a Proud Boys meeting in late 2020, court documents indicate, but denied he was a member of the far-right extremist group, saying he "would have joined the chapter, but it was too far away and there were no members of the Proud Boys in his local area."" (NPR)

Then, on January 6, Spain  was found to have illegally entered the U.S. Capitol building with the mob in Washington D.C. Spain was then charged with Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building following his participation in the Capitol riot.

Soon after, prosecutors say, Haffner, Loehrke and other rioters were able to breach the building through that door and can be seen in video footage taken inside the building. Additional details: Resident of OR; Brother also arrested
Short narrative: On March 23rd, 2021, Jonathanpeter Klein and his brother Matthew Leland Klein, both self-proclaimed members of the Proud Boys, were indicted on charges of 18:371 Conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2), 2 Obstruction of an Official Proceeding and Aiding and Abetting; 18:231(a)(3), 2 Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1361, 2 Destruction of Government Property and Aiding and Abetting; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; and 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds. Both pleaded not guilty to the charges, and their sentencing is pending. The Kleins came to the attention of law enforcement in fall 2020 when they attended Proud Boys rallies in Oregon. According to court records, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen at rallies in body armor and carrying a paintbull gun, and was photographed shooting the paintball gun at "an unknown target." On Jan. 6, federal prosecutors allege, Matthew and Jonathanpeter Klein joined with the mob and other members of the Proud Boys to breach the Capitol. Once inside, prosecutors said, Jonathanpeter Klein was seen engaging in a "celebratory exchange" with another Proud Boys member and displayed a Proud Boys hand signal. After the initial breach, the men allegedly exited the building and then "joined together to wrench open a secure door on the Capitol’s north side," allowing more rioters to enter the building "as part of a second or third wave of attacks."

On the day of the riot, he headed for the U.S. Capitol in a golf cart along with others named in the indictment. He then pleaded with officers to help a fellow rioter having a medical emergency and continued preventing police from closing doors into the Capitol building, according to the statement. Just a half-hour or so before that, FBI agents allege that Portlock pushed open metal barricades and used a large sheet of plywood to drive back a line of police officers in front of the Capitol. Portlock allegedly also joined a crowd of other protesters, chanting “heave-ho” and passing Capitol Police riot shields to other protesters in an attempt to push past officers blocking access to the tunnel into the Capitol. Portlock is a manager with Mitsubishi Motors, according to a LinkedIn page referenced in the FBI statement of facts. Court records show he was arrested on Nov. 3 in Smyrna, Tenn." (NPR)

Name of case: United States of America v. William Todd Wilson
Charges: 18:2384 Seditious conspiracy; 18:1512(c)(2) Obstruction of official proceeding
Additional details: Resident of NC; 3rd member of Oath Keepers to plead guilty to seditious conspiracy and agree to cooperate with the government's investigation
Short narrative: "William Todd Wilson is the third member of the Oath Keepers, an anti-government extremist group, to plead guilty to a charge of seditious conspiracy and agree to cooperate with the government's investigation into the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol. Wilson was a county-level leader of the Oath Keepers based in North Carolina, and he conspired with other members of the group to "oppose by force the lawful transfer of presidential power," according to a statement of offense Wilson signed and submitted in federal court as part of his guilty plea. In the days and weeks after the November 2020 presidential election, Wilson exchanged messages with other members of the Oath Keepers about how they believed Joe Biden had stolen the election and, as Oath Keepers leader Stewart Rhodes allegedly put it in one message, "we aren't getting through this without a civil war." On Jan. 5, 2021, Wilson drove from North Carolina to a hotel in Vienna, Va., which is near Washington, D.C., and brought with him an "AR-15-style rifle, a 9-millimeter pistol, approximately 200 rounds of ammunition, body armor, a camouflaged combat uniform, pepper spray, a large walking stick intended for use as a weapon, and a pocketknife," court documents state. Some members of the Oath Keepers allegedly remained at the hotel with a stash of weapons in order to act as a "Quick Reaction Force" that could bring arms into D.C. "in case of worst case scenarios," as Rhodes reportedly wrote in one message. On the day of the riot, Wilson breached the Capitol and helped force open doors to the building's rotunda, according to court documents. Prosecutors allege that at least 14 Oath Keepers breached the Capitol. Wilson left the building and later that evening gathered with Rhodes and other Oath Keepers at the Phoenix Park Hotel in Washington, D.C. At one point, court documents state, Rhodes called an unidentified person via speakerphone and "repeatedly implore[d] the individual to tell President Trump to call upon groups like the Oath Keepers to forcibly oppose the transfer of power." The person "denied Rhodes's request to speak directly with President Trump," according to court documents, which do not state what relationship that person may have had to Trump. Afterward, members of the group reportedly had dinner at an Olive Garden restaurant and discussed the possibility of taking further actions to fight the transfer of power. In the days after Jan. 6, Wilson deleted messages and information about the alleged plot and threw his cellphone into the Atlantic Ocean." (NPR)
Source description: Court documents, news articles, governmental reports and releases (DOJ)

Verdict: Guilty on some charges/not guilty on others
Additional details: Resident of FL; additionally sentenced to 36 months supervised release and $2000 restitution
Short narrative: Barry Bennet Ramey, 38, of Plantation, Florida was arrested and charged for his participation in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on January 6, 2021. A member of the Proud Boys, Ramey came into conflict with U.S. Capitol Police officers on the west side of the building; he was part of the mob pushing against the officers attempting to stop them from climbing the stairwell from the Lower West Terrace to the Upper West Terrace. It is here that Ramey sprayed officers in the eyes with an orange chemical agent, causing disorientation and pain. Though video footage of the incident was captured, the officers were not able to identify the perpetrator of the attack due to the impairment of their vision at the time. Ramey was identified using cell phone location data provided by AT&T--which showed that the phone belonging to Ramey had been using the cell site servicing the U.S. Capitol Building, testimony from the manager of Hilton Arlington Hotel, and identification from a former neighbor. Ramey was then arrested on charges of assaulting police, engaging in physical violence on Capitol grounds, entering a restricted building and civil disorder.

Name of case: United States of America v. Clendaniel & Russell
Charges: 18:1366 Conspiracy to Destroy an Energy Facility;
Additional details: Resident of Cantonsville, MD
Short narrative: Brandon Clint Russell (aka Homunculus & Raccoon), 27, and Sarah Beth Clendaniel (aka Nythra88 & Kali1889), 34, are accused of conspiring to destroy energy facilities in the area of Baltimore, Maryland and Delaware. The substations were located in Norrisville, Reisterstown and Perry Hall, MD, and the final 2 in Baltimore City. They had previously mentioned targeting a substation in Delaware, just beyond the MD border, as well. According to prosecutors, the plans was to damage 5 electrical substations in the Baltimore area with gunfire or through the use of Mylar balloons to cause an electrical short. Then defendants talked about destroying a "ring" around the city, leading to 'complete destruction' of the city through 'cascading failures'--timing the attacks when the electrical grid was already strained (i.e., hot summer or cold winter). The couple were both unknowingly speaking to federal informants in prison during their conspiracy, leading to their arrest. Although the plans began in prison, they continued after Russell was released on parole August 2021, and a focus on the infrastructure attacks began June 2022. The couple met while both were incarcerated in separate facilities--Russell was incarcerated for possessing bomb making materials as part of the Atomwaffen Division, and Clendaniel was imprisoned for robbery. Clendaniel told the informant the she expected to die of kidney disease within months and wanted the attacks to leave a statement. Investigators located a document, described as resembling a manifesto, which includes references to Ted Kaczynski, Anders Brevic and Adolf Hitler. The two reportedly were in contact from 2018 until their arrests in February 2023. Russell is a former Florida National Guard member and a founder of Atomwaffen, and Russell lived with Devon Arthurs, another Atomwaffen member arrested in 2017 for murder, but who had similarly planted to attack US electrical sites and nuclear power plants.
Source description: Charging document; Court document; Governmental reports and release;

Short narrative: "The FBI alleges that images from the Jan. 6, 2021, riot show William Hendry Mellors firing a canister of bear spray toward police officers on a staircase leading into the U.S. Capitol, according to court documents. “Took a nice beat down from Washington DC police tonight. Some tear gas and a riot baton. Broken ribs and some stitches needed,” Mellors later wrote on Parler as a caption for a close-up photo of what appears to be his own bloody ear, according to an FBI statement of facts. Mellors told FBI agents in April 2022 that he’d joined some “rabid” protesters at the Capitol on Jan. 6, also mentioning that a group of Proud Boys had asked him to “walk some ladies back to their hotel to protect them from Antifa” during the Trump rally in November 2020. He added that the Proud Boys “seemed like nice people.” When FBI agents interviewed Mellors a second time in May, he said he expected to be arrested and confirmed he brought two canisters of bear spray to Washington. He was arrested on July 18, 2022, in Houston" NPR

Charges: 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assault, Resist, Oppose, Impede, With a Person Engaged in Performance of Official Duties; 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Disorderly and Disruptive Conduct in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:641 Theft of Goverment Property
Additional details: Resident of Salem, NH
Short narrative: On June 13, 2023, a criminal complaint was issued against Richard Zachary Ackerman, 22, of Salem, NH for theft of government property, obstructing law enforcement during civil disorder, resisting a person engaged in official duties, entering and remaining on restricted grounds, and disorderly and disruptive conduct on restricted grounds. On January 6, 2021, Ackerman was part of the crowd that attempted to break a police barricade in the Lower West Terrace of the U.S. Capitol Building. During the riot, Ackerman acquired a U.S. Capitol police helmet, something he termed a "war trophy." Ackerman later attached a New England 131 sticker to the helmet, a sticker referencing the small neo-Nazi group named the Nationalist Social Club 13.

Name of case: United States of America v. Nathan Weeden
Charges: 18:241 CONSPIRACY AGAINST RIGHTS; 18:247(c), 18:247(d)(5) DAMAGE TO RELIGIOUS PROPERTY/OBSTRUCTION OF RELIGIOUS BELIEF - damaging religious property;
Additional details: Resident of Houghton, MI
Short narrative: "Nathan Weeden, 23, of Houghton, Michigan [was indicted] for conspiring with others and allegedly defacing Temple Jacob – a Jewish synagogue in Hancock, Michigan – with swastikas and symbols associated with The Base, a multi-state, white supremacist group...Weeden, along with other public documents filed in cases against alleged co-conspirators Richard Tobin of New Jersey and Yousef Barasneh of Wisconsin, support the following allegations. According to the indictment, in September 2019, Weeden, Tobin, and Barasneh – all members of The Base, a multi-state, white supremacist organization – allegedly used an encrypted messaging platform to discuss vandalizing property associated with African Americans and Jewish Americans. Weeden and his co-conspirators dubbed their plan, “Operation Kristallnacht,” which in German means “Night of Broken Glass” and is in reference to the events that took place on November 9th and 10th of 1938 in which Nazis murdered Jewish people and burned and destroyed their homes, synagogues, schools, and places of business. The indictment alleges that Weeden carried out this plan on September 21, 2019, when he spray-painted swastikas and symbols associated with The Base on the outside walls of Temple Jacob. Weeden is charged with two counts. The first count is for Conspiracy Against Rights under 18 U.S.C. § 241, a civil rights statute that makes it a crime to conspire to injure, oppress, threaten, or intimidate any person in the exercise of their rights...The second count is for Damage to Religious Property under 18 U.S.C. § 247, also a civil rights statute that makes it a crime to intentionally deface, damage, or destroy religious property because of the race or ethnic characteristics of individuals associated with that religious property. The maximum penalty under this statute is 1 year imprisonment and a $100,000 fine...The grand jury issued its two-count indictment against Nathan Weeden on June 27, 2023. The indictment was unsealed on June 29, 2023, after the defendant was arrested by the FBI. He remains in custody at this time. The court will schedule Weeden’s arraignment, detention hearing, and trial at a later date." (DOJ)
Source description: Charging document, Governmental report and release; Local News Articles;

Name of case: United States of America v. Tyler Bradley Dykes
Charges: 18:1752(a)(1) Entering and Remaining in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(a)(2) Knowingly Entering or Remaining in any Restricted Building or Grounds Without Lawful Authority; 18:1752(a)(4) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds; 18:1752(b)(1)(A) Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury; 18:231(a)(3) Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder; 18:111(a)(1) Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers; 40:5104(e)(2)(D) Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(F) Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building; 40:5104(e)(2)(G) Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building;
Additional details: Resident of Bluffton, SC; Attended Unite the Right in Charlotesville; former USMC
Short narrative: Tyler Dykes, 25, of Bluffton, SC, is charged with entering and remaining in a restricted building or grounds, knowingly entering or remaining in any restricted building or grounds without lawful authority, engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds, Engaging in Physical Violence in a Restricted Building or Grounds with a Deadly or Dangerous Weapon and Causing Significant Bodily Injury, Obstruction of Law Enforcement During Civil Disorder, Assaulting, Resisting, or Impeding Certain Officers, Disorderly Conduct in a Capitol Building, an Act of Physical Violence in the Capitol Grounds or Building, and Parading, Demonstrating, or Picketing in a Capitol Building. On January 6, 2021, Dykes participated in tearing down barriers and overwhelming a line of police officers, during which he took a riot shield. Dykes later revealed he was at the Capitol for fun, wanting to make a statement. Dykes was identified with the aid of crowd-sourced policing.
